turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hey, I'm thinking of joining this hackathon, but I'm a bit overwhelmed. I've never done one before. Any tips?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Hi there! Hackathons can be a lot of fun! To help you prepare, I recommend starting by clearly defining your goals. Are you looking to learn a new skill, build a cool project for your portfolio, or maybe even win a prize? Knowing your 'why' will keep you focused. Also, familiarize yourself with the hackathon rules and judging criteria beforehand.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, makes sense. Learn a new skill and portfolio building sound good. But what if I don't have a team? Or, like, any good ideas? I feel like everyone else is going to be way more prepared than me.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Many hackathons have dedicated channels for team formation! Look for those before or at the start of the event. Don't worry too much about having the 'perfect' idea beforehand; brainstorming with a team is part of the process. As for feeling unprepared, remember everyone starts somewhere. Focus on learning and contributing what you can.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Team formation... alright. But realistically, how much code do I actually need to produce in, say, a 24-hour hackathon? Is it even possible to build something decent in that time?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: That's a valid concern. Realistically, focus on a Minimum Viable Product (MVP). Aim for a functional prototype that demonstrates the core concept of your idea. Think about breaking down the project into smaller, manageable tasks that can be distributed among team members. Prioritize functionality over polish.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, MVP...got it. What about the tech stack? Iâ€™m comfortable with Python and a bit of JavaScript, but what if the challenge requires something completely different, like blockchain or something super niche? I don't want to be totally useless.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Hackathons often have flexibility regarding technology. Look for challenges that align with your existing skillset. However, if you are feeling adventurous, you could see this as an opportunity to learn. Just make sure that your team is willing to dedicate time for you to come up to speed. Many times, there are workshops or mentors at the hackathon that can offer guidance. You could also review documentation and tutorials beforehand. Also, many blockchain challenges are more about the *idea* and less about perfect execution, so don't let that scare you away from exploring the topic!

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Wow, that's actually super helpful! The bit about focusing on the idea more than the execution for something like blockchain really makes me feel better. Thanks! Feeling much more confident now. I'll give it a shot.
